xyz.acygn.mokapot

Class Authorisation

  • java.lang.Object
    • xyz.acygn.mokapot.Authorisation

  • public final class Authorisation
extends Object
    A class that can only be created via the internals of this library. It has two purposes. One is to allow methods to be made public (to get around visibility rules), whilst still being able to restrict who can call them indirectly via the Authorisation object. The other is to allow extra methods to be added to arbitrary existing classes without fear of naming clashes; as Java supports method overloading, two methods clash only if they have the same name and same parameters, and adding an Authorisation-typed parameter prevents any possible clash with existing code that does not use parameters of this type (i.e. any existing code written without reference to this library).

    Of course, this means that you should not mention this class in manually written code (outside this library); its purpose is to be used in generated code that's injected into packages outside this library. Mentioning it explicitly would somewhat defeat this. The class should be treated as package-private, even though it needs to be public for technical reasons (otherwise, generated code couldn't refer to it).

    Author:
    Alex Smith

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void verify()
      Verifies that this object is non-null and allows the access being requested.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • verify

        public void verify()
            throws SecurityException
        Verifies that this object is non-null and allows the access being requested. At present, no access checks are made beyond the Authorisation object itself existing.

        Because calls to this method are injected into generated code, it's important that its call pattern is as simple as possible in order to keep the generated code simple and small; as such, it has no return value, no parameters, and throws no checked exceptions. Should this method need in future to determine the reason it's being called, it would need to do that via inspection of the call stack.

        Throws:
        SecurityException - If there is a reason to deny the access being requested; at present, this never happens
